question: A.1 [1.0 point] In a subcritical reactor, Keff is increased from 0.931 to 0.946. Which ONE of the following is the amount of reactivity that was added to the core?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. ∆ρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2).  ∆ρ = (0.946-0.931)/(0.946*0.931) =0.017Δk/k =1.7%Δk/k
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. ∆ρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2).  ∆ρ = (0.946-0.931)/(0.946*0.931) =0.017Δk/k =1.7%Δk/k
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. ∆ρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2).  ∆ρ = (0.946-0.931)/(0.946*0.931) =0.017Δk/k =1.7%Δk/k
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. ∆ρ = (Keff1-Keff2)/(Keff1*Keff2).  ∆ρ = (0.946-0.931)/(0.946*0.931) =0.017Δk/k =1.7%Δk/k

question: A.2 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following isotopes has the highest thermal neutron cross section?

answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Table2.5, page 2-59.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Table2.5, page 2-59.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Table2.5, page 2-59.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Table2.5, page 2-59.

question: A.3 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following best describes the effects of moderator temperature increase on neutron multiplication?

answers.answer: a. Resonance escape probability ↑; Thermal non-leakage↓; Rod worth ↑
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2

answers.answer: b. Resonance escape probability ↓; Thermal non-leakage↓; Rod worth ↑
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2

answers.answer: c. Resonance escape probability ↑; Thermal non-leakage↑; Rod worth ↓
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2

answers.answer: d. Resonance escape probability ↓; Thermal non-leakage↓; Rod worth ↓
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.2

question: A.4 [1.0 point] Two critical reactors at low power are identical, except that Reactor 1 has a beta fraction of 0.0065 and Reactor 2 has a beta fraction of 0.0072. Which ONE of the following best describes the response if an equal amount of positive reactivity is inserted into both reactors?

answers.answer: a. Period of the Reactor 1 will be longer than the period of the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Equation Sheet.  τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]

answers.answer: b. Period of the Reactor 1 will be shorter than the period of the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Equation Sheet.  τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]

answers.answer: c. Power of the Reactor 1 will be higher than the power of the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Equation Sheet.  τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]

answers.answer: d. Power of the Reactor 1 will be lower than the power of the Reactor 2
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Equation Sheet.  τ = (ℓ*/ρ) + [(β-ρ)/λeffρ]

question: A.5 [1.0 point] Given the following Core Reactivity Data during startup: Control Rod, Total Rod Worth (%Δk/k), Rod Worth at Critical (%Δk/k)  SHIM Rod 1, 1.90, 1.30, REG Rod, 1.20, 1.00, SHIM Rod 2, 1.80, 1.00, Transient Rod, 2.60, 1.20. After reactor shutdown, the operator plans to remove the SHIM Rod 1 out of the reactor core for an inspection. Which ONE of the following would be the Shutdown Margin specified in the NETL Tech Spec if the operator removes the SHIM Rod 1?

answers.answer: a. violate the Tech Spec Shutdown Margin because the calculated result is 0.0 %Δk/k
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Shut Down Margin = 3rod worth at critical – SHIM rod 1 worth =  (1.3+1.0+1.0+1.2) – 1.9 =4.5-1.9 = 2.6 %Δk/k Tech Spec SDM =SDM– most reactivity control rod worth (Transient rod) = 2.6 – 2.6 = 0.0 %Δk/k  Violate the TS SDM : 0.0 %Δk/k  < 0.2 %Δk/k by TS 3.1.2

answers.answer: b. NOT violate the Tech Spec Shutdown Margin because the calculated result is 2.6 %Δk/k
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Shut Down Margin = 3rod worth at critical – SHIM rod 1 worth =  (1.3+1.0+1.0+1.2) – 1.9 =4.5-1.9 = 2.6 %Δk/k Tech Spec SDM =SDM– most reactivity control rod worth (Transient rod) = 2.6 – 2.6 = 0.0 %Δk/k  Violate the TS SDM : 0.0 %Δk/k  < 0.2 %Δk/k by TS 3.1.2

answers.answer: c. violate the Tech Spec Shutdown Margin because the calculated result is - 3.0 %Δk/k
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Shut Down Margin = 3rod worth at critical – SHIM rod 1 worth =  (1.3+1.0+1.0+1.2) – 1.9 =4.5-1.9 = 2.6 %Δk/k Tech Spec SDM =SDM– most reactivity control rod worth (Transient rod) = 2.6 – 2.6 = 0.0 %Δk/k  Violate the TS SDM : 0.0 %Δk/k  < 0.2 %Δk/k by TS 3.1.2

answers.answer: d. NOT violate the Tech Spec Shutdown Margin because the calculated result is 4.5 %Δk/k
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Shut Down Margin = 3rod worth at critical – SHIM rod 1 worth =  (1.3+1.0+1.0+1.2) – 1.9 =4.5-1.9 = 2.6 %Δk/k Tech Spec SDM =SDM– most reactivity control rod worth (Transient rod) = 2.6 – 2.6 = 0.0 %Δk/k  Violate the TS SDM : 0.0 %Δk/k  < 0.2 %Δk/k by TS 3.1.2

question: A.6 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following best describes the beta decay (β-1) of a nuclide?

answers.answer: The atomic mass number unchanged, and the number of protons increases by 1.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Chart of the Nuclides

answers.answer: The atomic mass number unchanged, and the number of protons decreases by 1.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Chart of the Nuclides

answers.answer: The atomic mass number increases by 1, and the number of protons decrease by 1.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Chart of the Nuclides

answers.answer: The atomic mass number increases by 2, and the number of protons increase by 1.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Chart of the Nuclides

question: A.7 [1.0 point] An example of a FISSIONABLE NUCLEI is:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, 1988 Section 3.2 page 3-2
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, 1988 Section 3.2 page 3-2
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, 1988 Section 3.2 page 3-2
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, 1988 Section 3.2 page 3-2

question: A.8 [1.0 point] The time period in which the MAXIMUM amount of Xe 135 will be present in the core is approximately 8 hours after:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 8.4, page 8-9
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 8.4, page 8-9

answers.answer: c. a power increase from 0% to 50%
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 8.4, page 8-9

answers.answer: d. a power decrease from 100% to 50%
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 8.4, page 8-9

question: A.9 [1.0 point] In a just critical reactor, adding $0.50 worth of reactivity in the SQUARE-WAVE MODE will cause:

answers.answer: a. A sudden drop in delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

answers.answer: b. The reactor period to be equal to (β-ρ)/λρ
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

answers.answer: c. A number of prompt neutrons equals to a number of delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

answers.answer: d. The resultant period to be a function of the prompt neutron lifetime (T=ℓ*/ρ)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

question: A.10 [1.0 point] During a reactor startup, criticality occurred at a LOWER ROD HEIGHT than the last startup. Which ONE of the following reasons could be the cause?

answers.answer: a. Higher moderator temperature (assume negative temperature coefficient).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Standard NRC question.

answers.answer: b. Insertion of a negative reactivity worth experiment.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Standard NRC question.

answers.answer: c. Burnout of a burnable poison.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Standard NRC question.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Standard NRC question.

question: A.11 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following will be the resulting stable reactor period when a $0.35 reactivity insertion is made into an exactly critical reactor core? Neglect any effects from prompt. Given β =0.0070 and λ=0.1

A.12 [1.0 point] You are the reactor operator performing two pulsing operations. The first pulse has a reactivity worth of $1.20 which results in a peak power of 200 MW. If the second pulse has a reactivity worth of $2.00, the corresponding peak power is: Given: β =0.0070

A.13 [1.0 point] A reactor with Keff = 0.7 contributes 2000 neutrons in the first generation. Changing from the first generation to the SECOND generation, how many total neutrons are there after the second generation?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.3, p. 5.6 2-nd generation=n + K*n=2000+1400=3400 neutrons
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.3, p. 5.6 2-nd generation=n + K*n=2000+1400=3400 neutrons
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.3, p. 5.6 2-nd generation=n + K*n=2000+1400=3400 neutrons
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 5.3, p. 5.6 2-nd generation=n + K*n=2000+1400=3400 neutrons

question: A.14 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following physical characteristics of the TRIGA fuel is the main contributor for the prompt negative temperature coefficient?

answers.answer: a. As the fuel heats up the resonance absorption peaks broaden and increases the likelihood of absorption in U-238 and/or Pu-240
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: TRIGA Fuel Design

answers.answer: b. As the fuel heats up a rapid increase in moderator temperature occurs through conduction and convection heat transfer mechanisms which adds negative reactivity
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: TRIGA Fuel Design

answers.answer: c. As the fuel heats up fission product poisons (e.g., Xe) increase in concentration within the fuel matrix and add negative reactivity via neutron absorption
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: TRIGA Fuel Design

answers.answer: d. As the fuel heats up the oscillating hydrogen in the ZrH lattice imparts energy to a thermal neutron, thereby increasing its mean free path and probability of escape
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: TRIGA Fuel Design

question: A.15 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following describes the term PROMPT DROP?

answers.answer: a. A reactor is subcritical at negative 80-second period.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: b. A reactor has attained criticality on prompt neutrons alone.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: c. The instantaneous change in power level due to inserting a control rod.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: d. The instantaneous change in power level due to withdrawing a control rod.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

question: A.16 [1.0 point] About two minutes following a reactor scram, the reactor period has stabilized and the power level is decreasing at a CONSTANT rate. Given that reactor power at time t0 is 90 kW power, what will it be five minutes later?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: P = P0 e-T/J = 90 kW H e(300sec/-80sec) = 900 kW H e-3.75 = 0.0235 H 90 kW = 2.1 kW
Correct. REFERENCE: P = P0 e-T/J = 90 kW H e(300sec/-80sec) = 900 kW H e-3.75 = 0.0235 H 90 kW = 2.1 kW
Incorrect. REFERENCE: P = P0 e-T/J = 90 kW H e(300sec/-80sec) = 900 kW H e-3.75 = 0.0235 H 90 kW = 2.1 kW
Incorrect. REFERENCE: P = P0 e-T/J = 90 kW H e(300sec/-80sec) = 900 kW H e-3.75 = 0.0235 H 90 kW = 2.1 kW

question: A.17 [1.0 point] The reactor is subcritical with the count rate of 100 counts per second (cps) and Keff of 0.950. The control rods are withdrawn until the count rate is doubled. What is the new value of Keff?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Count1*(1-Keff1) = Count2*(1-Keff2) 100*(1-0.950) = 200*(1-Keff2) 100*(1-0.95) = 200(1- Keff2);  Keff2 = 0.975
Correct. REFERENCE: Count1*(1-Keff1) = Count2*(1-Keff2) 100*(1-0.950) = 200*(1-Keff2) 100*(1-0.95) = 200(1- Keff2);  Keff2 = 0.975
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Count1*(1-Keff1) = Count2*(1-Keff2) 100*(1-0.950) = 200*(1-Keff2) 100*(1-0.95) = 200(1- Keff2);  Keff2 = 0.975
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Count1*(1-Keff1) = Count2*(1-Keff2) 100*(1-0.950) = 200*(1-Keff2) 100*(1-0.95) = 200(1- Keff2);  Keff2 = 0.975

question: A.18 [1.0 point] Xenon-135 (Xe135) is produced in the reactor by two methods. One is directly from fission; the other is indirectly from the decay of:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.

question: A.19 [1.0 point] The reactor is on a CONSTANT positive period. Which ONE of the following power changes will take the longest time to complete?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Time is related to ratio of final power to initial power. 2:1 is the largest ratio.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Time is related to ratio of final power to initial power. 2:1 is the largest ratio.
Correct. REFERENCE: Time is related to ratio of final power to initial power. 2:1 is the largest ratio.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Time is related to ratio of final power to initial power. 2:1 is the largest ratio.

question: A.20 [1.0 point] Delayed neutrons are produced by:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.2.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.2.
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.2.

answers.answer: d. directly from the fission process
